questions.text: Which of the following nerves supply the greatest area of sensibility of the foot?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tibial The tibial nerve supplies nearly all of the sole through its branches: medial calcaneal, medial plantar, and lateral plantar nerves.

Highyeild:

Course: Descends through popliteal fossa to the posterior compartment of leg. Accompanied with posterior tibial vessels. Passes behind the medial malleolus (deep to flexor retinaculum) to reach the sole of foot where it divides into 2 terminal branches, (Medial & Lateral planter nerves).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . The sural nerve supplies the lateral border of the foot, and the saphenous nerve provides the medial wall and medial aspect of the dorsum. Option: B. Supplies sensation to the medial side of the foot Option: D. The deep peroneal nerve supplies the dorsal aspect of the first web space, and the superficial peroneal nerve provides the rest of the dorsum.

questions.text: Which of the following ossification centers is first to appear?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cuboid The calcaneum (anterior), talus and cuboid ossification centers are usually present at birth.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The intermediate cuneiform and navicular appear during the third year Option: B. The medial cuneiform appears during the second year Option: C. The lateral cuneiform appears during the first year The posterior calcaneal center appears during the eighth year.

questions.text: The Lisfranc ligament’s attachments are?

options.label: A
options.text: Intermediate cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal on the plantar surface

options.label: B
options.text: Medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal on the plantar surface

options.label: C
options.text: Medial cuneiform to the base of second metatarsal on dorsal surface

options.label: D
options.text: Intermediate cuneiform to the base of first metatarsal on dorsal surface

questions.correct_answer: B. Medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal on the plantar surface
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal on the plantar surface The Lisfranc ligament is a robust oblique ligament, which arises from the plantar-lateral aspect of the medial cuneiform, passes in front of the intercuneiform ligament and inserts into the plantar-medial aspect of the second metatarsal. In about 20% of patients, there are two separate bands of the ligament (dorsal and plantar).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Lisfranc is attached to medial cuneiform, not intermediate cuneiform Option: C. Lisfranc ligament is majorly present on the plantar surface, not dorsal Option: D. Lisfranc is attached to medial cuneiform, not intermediate cuneiform

questions.text: Which of the following is not supplied by branches of the tibial nerve?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extensor digitorum brevis The tibial nerve divides into the medial calcaneal (sensory), medial plantar, and lateral plantar nerves after it passes behind the medial malleolus. The medial plantar nerve supplies the flexor digitorum brevis, first lumbrical, flexor hallucis brevis and abductor hallucis. The lateral plantar nerve supplies the abductor digit minimi, flexor digiti minimi brevis, interossei, second to fourth lumbricals, adductor hallucis and flexor digitorum accessorius. The extensor digitorum brevis is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve Extensor digitorum brevis supplied by Deep peroneal nerve

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option :A. First lumbrical supplied by medial plantar nerve, branch of tibial nerve Option: B. Third lumbrical is supplied by lateral plantar nerve, branch of tibial nerve Option: D. Abductor hallucis supplied by medial plantar nerve, branch of tibial nerve

questions.text: Which of the following nerves supplies sensory innervation to the first web space of the foot?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Deep peroneal nerve Deep peroneal nerve innervates EDB, and EHB in the foot, providing sensation to the first dorsal web space The deep peroneal nerve is a branch of the common peroneal nerve. The standard peroneal nerve courses anteriorly around the neck of the fibula and lies on the anterior cortex beneath the peroneus longus muscle. Here it divides into its deep and superficial branches. The deep peroneal nerve is accompanied by the anterior tibial artery, as it passes distally between the anterior and extensor hallucis longus. It supplies all of the muscles of the anterior compartment of the lower leg, and gives a sensory branch to the first web space of the foot

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. a medial branch of the Superficial peroneal nerve supplies the dorsomedial aspect of the hallux Option: C. Sural nerve provides dorsal sensory in the 4th web space Option: D. Saphenous nerve supplies medial side of foot

questions.text: Which of the following structures is located most posteriorly on the medial side of the ankle?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Flexor hallucis longus FLEXOR hallucis longus is a powerful muscle located on the posterior aspect of the fibula below the deep fascia of the calf. The structures on the medial side of the ankle are arranged in the following order: Tibialis posterior, flexor digitorum longus, Artery, Nerve, flexor hallucis longus (mnemonic – Tall Doctors Are Never Happy.)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Lies anteriorly behind Tibialis anterior Option B. FDL lies posterior to Tibialis posterior Option D. Lies more anterior to FHL as shown the image

questions.text: Injury to which of the following nerves results in winging of the scapula?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Long thoracic nerve The long thoracic nerve is derived from the ventral rami of C5, C6, and C7. It runs downward, passing in front of or behind the middle scalene muscle. It then descends onto the anterior surface of the serratus anterior muscle, giving branches to supply it. Winging of scapula most commonly occurs when there is damage or impaired innervation to serratus anterior

Highyeild:

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured Fracture clavicle Brachial plexus Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve Proximal humerus fracture Axillary nerve Shaft of humerus fracture Radial nerve Supracondylar fracture humerus Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve Medial condyle of humerus Ulnar nerve Posterior dislocation elbow Ulnar nerve >Median nerve Monteggia fracture Posterior interosseous nerve Volkman's ischemic contracture Anterior interosseous nerve Hook of hamate fracture Deep branch of the ulnar nerve Lunate dislocation Median nerve Wrist injury Median nerve Posterior hip dislocation Sciatic nerve Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve Proximal tibial fractures and ankle injury Posterior tibial nerve Fracture neck of the fibula Lateral popliteal nerve (common peroneal nerve)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Axillary nerve supplies structures like Deltoid, teres minor, shoulder joint capsule Option: B. Suprascapular nerve supplies supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscle Option: C. Medial pectoral nerve supplies pectoralis major

questions.text: During the anatomy practical, the following diagram was shown to students, and a few questions were asked about the blood supply of bones. Nutrient artery, metaphyseal, and epiphyseal artery supply different parts of the long bones. The nutrient artery of the bone does not nourish.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Outer 1/3rd of the cortex

Highyeild:

Blood supply to the long bones comes from these three primary sources: Nutrient artery system Metaphyseal-epiphyseal system Periosteal system The nutrient artery system is a high-pressure system that branches from major systemic arteries. It enters the cortex via the nutrient foramen and then migrates into the medullary canal.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B . There it branches into ascending and descending branches that further branch out into arterioles and supply the inner 2/3 of bone within the Haversian system. Option C . The metaphyseal-epiphyseal arteries arise from the periarticular plexus, which is found around the common area of a long bone, e.g., Geniculate Arteries. The periosteal artery system is a low-pressure system that supplies the outer 1/3 of bone and is connected through Haversian (parallel to the long axis) and Volkmann canals (perpendicular to the long axis). These canals are part of the osteon structure of the cortex. Perichondrial artery is the primary source of nutrition of the growth plate

questions.text: Identify the bone and mention the tendon where it is found

options.label: C
options.text: Patella, tendon of lateral head of gastrocnemius

options.label: D
options.text: Fabella, tendon of lateral head of gastrocnemius

questions.correct_answer: D. Fabella, tendon of lateral head of gastrocnemius
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fabella, tendon of lateral head of gastrocnemius Given xray is of a sesamoid bone found in the tendon of lateral head of gastrocnemius, where it moves over lateral condyle of femur. Its popularly known as Fabella. Its present in 10-30% of individuals. While, Patella is the largest sesamoid bone of the body, found in the tendon of quadriceps femoris.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Patellar bone is present anteriorly attached to the quadriceps femoris tendon, forming a part of the extensor apparatus Option: B. Fabella is found with tendon of lateral head of gastrocnemius Option: C. Patellar bone is present anteriorly attached to the quadriceps femoris tendon, forming a part of the extensor apparatus and not in the lateral head of gastrocnemius

questions.text: What type of joint is Costochondral joint?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Synchondrosis Costochondral joints are the Primary Cartilaginous Joints, also known as Synchondrosis. There are three main types of joints in our body.

Highyeild:

Various Types Of Joints In Thoracic Wall Include: SYNOVIAL JOINT COSTOVERTEBRAL JOINT COSTOTRANSVERSE JOINT INTERCHONDRAL JOINTS PRIMARY CARTILAGINOUS JOINT/SYNCHONDROSIS COSTOCHONDRAL JOINT SECONDARY/CARTILAGINOUS/SYMPHYSIS JOINT XIPHISTERNAL AND MANUBRIOSTERNAL JOINT

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - These are :- table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} TYPE SUBTYPES Fibrous Joints (Immovable joints, also known as Synarthroses) Sutures Syndesmosis e.g (Tibiofibular and Radio Ulnar) Gomphosis Cartilaginous Joints Primary Cartilaginous Joints (Synchondrosis) table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} slightly mobile joints, also known as Amphiarthroses Secondary Cartilaginous Joints (Symphysis Synovial Joints freely mobile joints, also known as Diarthroses) Ball and Socket joints Saddle joints Condylar joints Ellipsoidal joints Hinge joints Pivot joints Plane joints Option: A. Example of synovial joints are Elbow joint, CMC joint, AC joint, Atlantoaxial joint, MCP joint, hip joint Option: C. Synarthrosis is a joint that is essentially immobile, example - fibrous joints of skull sutures and cartilaginous manubriosternal joint Option: D. Syndesmosis joint is a fibrous joint held together by ligaments example - distal tibiofibular joint

questions.text: Identify the vertebra and the marked structure?

options.label: D
options.text: Thoracic vertebra and Superior articular process

questions.correct_answer: B. Axis vertebra and Odontoid Process
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Axis vertebra and Odontoid Process The odontoid process, or dens, is a superior projecting bony element from the second cervical vertebrae(C2, or the axis)

Highyeild:

Other vertebrae with marked structures:-

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Atlas is the first cervical vertebrae Option C. C7 vertebrae has a posterior prominence called spinous process, as shown in the diagram Option D. The vertebrae in the image is the second cervical vertebrae, not thoracic

questions.text: A 24-year-old male slipped from his scooter and fell over his left developed pain and swelling at the base of his left thumb. He was taken to a nearby hospital, where an x-ray was done and he was diagnosed to have a fractured base of the first metacarpal left hand, popularly known as Bennett’s Fracture. Which muscle force is responsible for the proximal migration of the shaft of the first metacarpal
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Abductor Pollicis Longus Abductor pollicis longus displaces the first metacarpal proximally

Highyeild:

Bennett’s fracture is a fracture subluxation of the first carpometacarpal joint, with a sizeable palmar anterior marginal fracture fragment. The metacarpal is also displaced proximally by the Abductor Pollicis Longus muscle.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Adductor pollicis adducts and supinates the first metacarpal Option C. Flexor pollicis longus is not the deforming muscle of Bennett fracture Option D. Flexor pollicis brevis is not deforming muscle of Bennett fracture

questions.text: Forty-four years old obese diabetic lady has pain, numbness, tingling, and sometimes shock-like sensation in the lateral three-and-a-half part of her hand. Pain increases while typing on a laptop. She went to meet an orthopaedician. Her x-rays were normal. Tinel’s sign and Phalen's test were positive. After USG and NCV, she was diagnosed to have carpal tunnel syndrome. Which structure is the most radial or laterally placed in the carpal tunnel?
questions.correct_answer: D. Tendon of Flexor Pollicis Longus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tendon of Flexor Pollicis Longus Symptoms of this lady are consistent with the diagnosis of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome is a compressive neuropathy of the median nerve at the level of the wrist.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Tendons of Flexor Digitorum Superficialis is a part of the carpal tunnel but lie more medially Option: B. Tendons of Flexor Digitorum Superficialis is a part of the carpal tunnel but lie more medially Option: C. Median nerve is a part of the carpal tunnel but lies medial to FPL tendon

questions.text: A 27-year-old male fell on an outstretched hand, and after the trauma, he could not lift his right arm. He has injured one of the long bones. This bone has two primary centers of ossification and ossify last. Identify the long bone.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Clavicle

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: Radius has 3 ossification centres Option B: Scapula have 4 ossification centres Option D: Humerus have 8 ossification centres

questions.text: In a final anatomy viva, a first year student was given a model of a backbone and was asked how many vertebrae, mobile segments, and pair of spinal nerves are present in the adult human body. What would be the right choice among the following options?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

33, 24, 31 In humans, the vertebral column usually consists of 33 vertebrae, placed in series and connected by ligaments and intervertebral discs. Usually there are 7 cervical, 12 thoracic, 5 lumbar, 5 sacral, and 4 caudal (coccygeal) vertebrae.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. There are only 24 mobile segments, not 33, as sacral and coccygeal vertebrae are fused Option: C. There are 31 pairs of spinal nerves, not 33 Option: D. There are only 24 mobile segments, not 29 as sacral and coccygeal vertebrae are fused

questions.text: An orthopaedician was treating a 63 years old lady for osteoporosis. Her routine blood samples were all normal. He decides to evaluate her with Bone Turnover Markers further. Identify the correct bone formation/resorption markers among the below options: Serum Tartarate Resistant Acid Phosphatase Serum Osteocalcin Serum Bone Sialoprotein Urine and Serum cross-linked C-telopeptide Serum Bone specific Alkaline phosphatase Select the correct answer from the below option:

options.label: D
options.text: Only 1 is a marker for bone resorption

questions.correct_answer: C. 2, 5 are markers for bone formation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 5 are markers for bone formation Serum osteocalcin and serum bone-specific cross-linked C-telopeptide are markers of bone formation.

Highyeild:

Bone formation markers Bone resorption markers Osteocalcin C-Telopeptide of Collagen Cross-links (CTX) Bone Specific Alkaline Phosphatase (BSAP) N-Telopeptide of Collagen Cross-links (NTx) Carboxyterminal propeptide of Type I Collagen (P1CP) Pyridinolines Aminoterminal propeptide of Type I Collagen (P1NP) Deoxypyridinoline Tartrate-Resistant Acid Phosphatase (TRAP)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. 1,3.4 are bone resorption markers Option: B. Serum TRAP is a bone resorption marker Option: D. Serum TRAP is a bone resorption marker

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the layers of the growth plate?

options.label: A
options.text: Zone of hypertrophy is the weakest layer

options.label: B
options.text: Achondroplasia affects the zone of hypertrophy

options.label: C
options.text: Normal matrix mineralization occurs in the upper hypertrophic zone

options.label: D
options.text: Zone of hypertrophy is not involved in rickets

questions.correct_answer: A. Zone of hypertrophy is the weakest layer
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zone of hypertrophy is the weakest layer Growth plate is divided into four layers/zones. They are Reserve zone / Germinal zone Proliferative zone Hypertrophy zone Zone of ossification

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B . Achondroplasia affects proliferative zone Option C: Normal matrix mineralization occurs in the lower hypertrophic zone: chondrocytes increase five times in size, accumulate calcium in their mitochondria, die, and release calcium from matrix vesicles. Option D : In Rickets, the Hypertrophic zone gets widened.

questions.text: Which of the following cells involved in bone morphology does not originate from the bone?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Osteoclast Multinucleated irregular giant cells Derived from hematopoietic cells in macrophage lineage Monocyte progenitors form giant cells by fusion

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A – Osteoblast Builder cells Functions Form bone Regulate osteoclastic activity Option: B - Osteocytes: Maintain bone Constitute 90% of the cells in the mature skeleton Former osteoblasts surrounded by newly formed matrix High nucleus/cytoplasm ratio Option: D - Osteoid cells: Appear as cuboid cells aligned in layers along immature osteoid Are derived from undifferentiated mesenchymal stem cells These stem cells line haversian canals, endosteum, and periosteum. Become osteoblasts under conditions of low strain and increased oxygen Tension.

questions.text: Certain cells play an active role in bone formation and resorption, while others have a passive role. Which cells are known as the “silent cells” of the bone matrix?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Osteocyte Osteocyte are known as quiescent or silent cells. Bone formation and resorption are linked Resorption mechanism Osteoclasts possess a ruffled (brush) border and surrounding clear zone Border consists of plasma membrane enfoldings that increase surface area Bind to bone surfaces through cell attachment (anchoring) proteins.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. OSTEOCLAST have an active role in bone resorption Option: B. OSTEOBLAST have an active role in bone formation Option: D. Osteoid cells have become osteoblasts under conditions of low strain and increased oxygen Tension

questions.text: Bone muscle and tendon comprise collagens as one of its base properties. Any deficiency in certain collagen will lead to defects in its structural properties. Which collagen predominates in bone and cartilage?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type 1 and 2 Organic components: 40% of the dry weight of bone Collagen (90% of organic components)

Highyeild:

Types Locations Type I Bone, skin, dentin, cornea, blood vessels, fibrocartilage and tendon Type II Cartilaginous tissues Type III Skin, ligaments, blood vessels and internal organs Type IV Basement membrane in various tissues Type V Blood vessel wall, synovium, corneal stoma, tendon, lung, bone, cartilage and skeletal muscle

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Bone has type 1 collagen and Cartilage has type 2 Option: B. Cartilage has type 2, not type 3 collagen Option: D. Cartilage has type 2 collagen, not type 4

questions.text: Hydroxyapatite crystals are made up of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ca &PO4 Hydroxyapatite crystals are made up of Ca& PO4

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Hydroxyapatite crystals do not contain Mg Option C. Hydroxyapatite crystals do not contain Mn and Zn Option D. Hydroxyapatite crystals do not contain Zn Organic components: 40% of the dry weight of bone

questions.text: Bones grow in length and breadth and gain strength as they begin to ossify. The increase in length of the bone is what type of growth?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Interstitial growth

Highyeild:

GROWTH OF LONG BONES a. Appositional growth ↑ in width of bone → Meta /Diaphysis b. Interstitial growth ↑in length of bone →Epiphysis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Increase in width of the bone is by appositional growth of bone Option C. Increase in length of bone is interstitial growth, not longitudinal growth, a bone grows longitudinally by enchondral ossification at the physis Option D. Increase in length of bone is interstitial growth, not concentric growth

questions.text: Increase in width of bone is what type of growth?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Appositional growth Increase in the preexisting diameter of bone is achieved by the deposition of bone tissue on two surfaces of bone, namely the endosteal and the periosteal; endosteal is the inner surface of bone which encloses the cavity present in it, and the periosteal is a thin layer of connective tissues that covers the outer surface of bones as a result of which new layer is formed on the bone and increase its diameter.

Highyeild:

GROWTH OF LONG BONES a. Appositional growth ↑ in width of bone → Meta /Diaphysis b. Interstitial growth ↑in length of bone →Epiphysis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Increase in length of the bone is by interstitial growth of bone Option: C. Increase in width of bone is appositional growth, not longitudinal growth, a bone grows longitudinally by enchondral ossification at the physis Option: D. Increase in width of bone is appositional growth, not concentric growth

questions.text: Estimation of osteoid is done by?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tetracycline labeling Tetracycline double labeling is a process used to calculate data on bone turnover. Patients are given tetracycline in this procedure, which binds to the newly formed bone. This appears on biopsy samples as a linear fluorescence. A second dose of tetracycline is given 11-14 days after the first dose; this occurs on a biopsy sample as a second line of fluorescence.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. DEXA scan is done to measure bone density Option: C. Bone biopsy is a procedure in which suspected bone samples are removed Option: D. Quantitative CT scan used to measure bone mineral density

questions.text: Osteocytes regulate negative feedback in osteoblast bone deposition through?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sclerostin Sclerostin secreted by osteocytes helps negative feedback on osteoblasts’ bone deposition.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Calcitonin acts by - Decreasing Ca from bones and Decreasing Ca reabsorption from the kidney Option: C. Testosterone does not provide negative feedback in osteoblast bone deposition Option: D. Calcium is a mineral used in bone formation

questions.text: Type of bone formation in a fracture callus Is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Enchondral ossification In Enchondral ossification Undifferentiated cells secrete cartilaginous matrix and differentiate into chondrocytes. Bone replaces the cartilage model; cartilage is not converted to bone

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Direct bone formation without intermediate phase or template precursor, No cartilaginous phase Option C. Growth in bones occurs in two ways, either longitudinally or increase in the width of the bone size. This increase in the length size of the bone is referred to as interstitial growth, whereas the increase in the preexisting diameter or width size of bones is referred to as appositional growth Option D. Bone growth occurring via the secondary ossification center

questions.text: Bone remodeling is actively seen in young children following a fracture union. The younger the age, the greater the ability for remodeling. The type of bone formation is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Appositional ossification Osteoblasts align on the existing bone surface and lay down new bone. Examples: Periosteal bone enlargement (width) Bone formation phase of bone remodeling GROWTH OF LONG BONES a. Appositional growth ↑ in width of bone → Meta /Diaphysis b. Interstitial growth ↑in length of bone →Epiphysis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Enchondral ossification Bone formation through a hyaline cartilage template/model Eg - Most long bones Option: B. - Intramembranous ossification Occurs without a cartilage model Undifferentiated mesenchymal cells aggregate into layers (or membranes), differentiate into osteoblasts, and deposit an organic matrix that mineralizes. Examples: Embryonic flat bone formation Bone formation during distraction osteogenesis Blastema bone (in young children with amputations) Option D. – Secondary ossification Bone growth occurring via the secondary ossification center

questions.text: Which of there is not a marker for increased osteoblastic activity:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased acid phosphatase BONE formation marker is alkaline phosphatase and not acid phosphatase Tartrate resistant acid phosphatase is an osteoclastic marker

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. ALP is an osteoblastic marker Option C. Procollagen is an osteoblastic marker Option D. Osteocalcin is an osteoblastic marker

questions.text: Ilizarov technique is a method of treatment used for deformity correction and limb shortening based on distraction osteogenesis. The type of bone formation is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intramembranous ossification Intramembranous ossification Occurs without a cartilage model Undifferentiated mesenchymal cells aggregate into layers (or membranes), differentiate into osteoblasts, and deposit an organic matrix that mineralizes. Examples: Embryonic flat bone formation Bone formation during distraction osteogenesis Blastema bone (in young children with amputations)

Highyeild:

Two Types of Ossification Endochondral ossification Bone forms by replacing hyaline cartilage Bones called cartilage (endochondral) bones Forms most of skeleton Intramembranous ossification Bone develops from fibrous membrane Bones called membrane bones Forms flat bones, e.g. clavicles and cranial bones

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A - Enchondral ossification Bone formation through a hyaline cartilage template/model Eg - Most long bones Option: C -Appositional ossification Osteoblasts align on the existing bone surface and lay down new bone. Examples: Periosteal bone enlargement (width) Bone formation phase of bone remodeling Option: D – Secondary ossification Bone growth occurring via the secondary ossification center

questions.text: All the following are the functions of the hormone PTH (parathormone) except:

options.label: A
options.text: Maintains blood calcium levels by resorption of bone

options.label: B
options.text: Lowers serum phosphorous levels by inhibiting tubular resorption of phosphate

options.label: C
options.text: Enhances the mineralizing effect of Vit. D

questions.correct_answer: C. Enhances the mineralizing effect of Vit. D
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Enhances the mineralizing effect of Vit. D PTH decreases phosphate reabsorption at the proximal convoluted tubule REGULATION OF CALCIUM AND PHOSPHATE METABOLISM A. PTH → Parathyroid Hormone 1. Intestine: No direct effect 2. Kidney: ↑ conversion of Vit. D (to active form) 3. Bone: Resorption (Net: Ca ↑, Po y ↓) B. Vit. D 3 1. Kidney: ↑ Ca absorption, ↓ PO 4 2. Intestine: 1 absorption 3. Bone: Net: Ca↑ , PO 4 ↑ ) C. Calcitonin → Bone resorption inhibition (Ca↓)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. PTH is secreted in response to low blood serum calcium (Ca2+) levels. PTH indirectly stimulates osteoclast activity within the bone matrix (osteon) to release more ionic calcium (Ca2+) into the blood to elevate a low serum calcium level Option B. PTH-dependent stimulation of phosphate excretion via downregulation of sodium-dependent phosphate co-transporter and thereby decreasing phosphate reabsorption from proximal renal tubules Option D. PTH is secreted in response to low blood serum calcium (Ca2+) levels. PTH indirectly stimulates osteoclast activity within the bone matrix (osteon) to release more ionic calcium (Ca2+) into the blood to elevate a low serum calcium level

questions.text: All the following are the various microscopic zones of the growth plate except:
questions.explanation:

Zone of amorphous crystallization Zone of amorphous crystallization is not a zone of growth plate rest are the microscopic zones present in the growth plate

Zone of proliferation - Proliferating cartilage cells are seen, Number of cells in this zone shows activity in growth plate Option: C. Zone of maturation - In this area, cells become impregnated with calcium salts, calcification of matrix

questions.text: Increased alkaline phosphate is most commonly seen in?

Solution:

No increase of osteoblastic activity is seen in Osteoporosis Serum bone ALP concentration is an index of Osteoblastic activity

questions.text: Which of the following techniques (invasive) can be used for accurate measurement of Osteoid deposition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tetracycline deposition technique Tetracycline deposition labeling is an invasive technique to estimate the rate of osteoid formation. Rate of new bone remodeling gauged by labeling bone on two separate occasions (2 weeks apart). Tetracycline is taken up by bone, producing a fluorescent strip on UV light. By measuring the distance between 2 labels, the rate of new bone formation is calculated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. DEXA scan is done to measure bone density Option C. Bone biopsy is a procedure in which suspected bone samples are removed Option D. SPECT scan used to test how blood flows to tissues and organs

questions.text: The root value of the long thoracic nerve is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C 5,6,7 Long thoracic nerve arises from the ventral rami of C5, C6, and C7 LONG THORACIC NERVE Anatomy: The nerve arises from the ventral rami of C5, C6, and C7. It descends behind the brachial plexus on the lateral surface of the serratus anterior, which it supplies. Test: The serratus anterior muscle can be examined by asking the patient to push against a wall with both hands. The medial border of the scapula on the affected side will become prominent (winging of the scapula)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION A. Long thoracic nerve arises from the ventral rami of C5, C6 and C7 OPTION B. Long thoracic nerve arises from the ventral rami of C5, C6 and C7 OPTION D. Long thoracic nerve arises from the ventral rami of C5, C6 and C7
